note:
您好，欢迎回到股权，TechCrunch的风险资本聚焦播客，在那里我们解开了头条新闻背后的数字。
 本周，娜塔莎和丹尼，否则被称为你的两个新的最喜欢的书的影响者（里面的笑话，如果你听节目，你会得到的），跳上麦克风，让每个人都扔新闻，在背景中有恩典和克里斯。
   明智的宣布计划通过直销上市公开，使其成为在伦敦证券交易所上首次亮相的最大公司。
 Andreessen Horowitz随着将来出版，所以Danny和Natasha轮流宣布为什么每个人都热的博客，以及未来可能是什么。
 Harry Stebbings在20VC上推出了新的140米基金。 Natasha驳回了为什么它对新兴基金经理事项有关，为什么它可能会对微型资金的增长潜力进行一些担忧。
 在我们离开我们通常编程的媒体和风险投资情况后，我们转向社区。 Commsor购买了Interysy以构建所有未公开的价格的社区工具。
 Danny发现了与书店的业余爱好市场，这是一个刚刚筹集了2000万美元的创业公司，使阅读体验更多与作者LED讨论更加乐于互动。然后，Edtech Convo继续与本周更加筹备的7000万美元的融资活动。 
丹尼有铲子在Gusto的首次收购以及Clair，这是一种跳过直接存款和直接拨打薪水的工具。  要关闭资金圆形部分，我们谈到了Carbyne使紧急情况更加精简，而纳柴斯认为是一周的标题：Neo4J为基于图形的数据分析占据了企业的数据分析。  要关闭，我们与HBCUVC的100万美元基金谈到了忽视的创始人，以及onramp抱负的投资者。  好吧，正如你所说，这是你谦卑的主持人的繁忙写作和讲话周。 我们很感激有机会，并将在星期一回到你的耳边。  股权每周一凌晨7点下午7点，PST和星期四下午尽快，我们可以在苹果播客，阴云密布，Spotify和所有演员中订阅我们。  P.S. 我们迫不及待地想在下周看到你的直播显示。 如果你没有抓住免费门票，请得到它们！
note_en:
Hello and welcome back to Equity, TechCrunch’s venture capital-focused podcast, where we unpack the numbers behind the headlines.
 This week,  Natasha and  Danny, otherwise known as your two new favorite Book influencers (inside joke, you’ll get if you listen to the show), hopped on the mics to take everyone threw the news, with  Grace and  Chris in the background.
   Wise announced plans to go public via direct listing, making it the biggest company to use this route to debut on the London Stock Exchange.
 Andreessen Horowitz goes into publishing with Future, so Danny and Natasha took turns fawning over why everyone has hot takes about a blog, and what could be in the future for Future.
 Harry Stebbings turned up the volume on 20VC with new $140M fund. Natasha broke down why it matters for emerging fund managers, and why it might quiet some concerns about the growth potential of micro-funds.
 After we left our usually programmed media and venture conversation, we turned to community.   Commsor bought Meetsy to build community tools for all for an undisclosed price.
 Danny found hobby-market fit with BookClub,  a startup that just raised $20 million to make reading experiences more engaging with author-led discussions. Then, the edtech convo continued with  Formative’s $70 million financing event from this week.
 Danny had the scoop on  Gusto’s first-ever acquisition as well as Clair, a tool that is skipping the direct deposit and  heading straight for the paycheck.
 To close out the funding round section, we spoke about  Carbyne making emergencies more streamlined, and what Natasha argued is the headline o’ the week:   Neo4j raises Neo$325m as graph-based data analysis takes hold in enterprise.
 To close, we spoke to  HBCUvc’s $1 million fund to back overlooked founders, and onramp aspiring investors.
 Well, as you can tell, it’s been a busy writing and speaking week for your humble hosts. We’re grateful for the opportunity, and will be back in your ears on Monday.
 Equity drops every Monday at 7:00 a.m. PST and Thursday afternoon as fast as we can get it out, so subscribe to us on   Apple Podcasts ,   Overcast ,   Spotify  and all the casts.
 P.S. We can’t wait to see you all at our live show next week.  If you haven’t grabbed free tickets, GET THEM!
title: 拥有薪水是金融气成功的关键
title_en: Owning the paycheck is the key to fintech success

note:
数百年多年前，人们开发了巧妙的方法，以确保他们的信件窥探眼睛 - 他们只用纸张，粘合剂和褶皱来做。
 晚上于1587年2月8日晚上，一个被监禁的玛丽女王苏格兰女王组成了她的最后一封信给她的姐夫。 ＆＃34;今晚，晚餐后，我一直在建议我的判决：我要像早上八个罪犯一样被执行，＆＃34;她写了。 ＆＃34;天主教的信仰和我的上帝的主张 - 赋予英国王冠的权利是我被谴责的两个问题。＆＃34;令她悲伤的接受她的命运，她让他照顾她的事务并支付她的仆人，祝他＆＃34;健康和漫长而幸福的生活＆＃34;
 玛丽写完后写作后，她开始折叠信来保护其内容。她没有想要她的俘虏窥探 - 特别不是她表弟女王伊丽莎白I.然而，在1500年代没有使用信封 - 尤其是纸张昂贵 - 而且当时没有值得信赖的邮政局。
 相反，玛丽从纸质边缘切割薄薄的条带，然后将她的信息折叠成一个小矩形。通过矩形戳刀子来制作一个洞，然后她通过搭配地带，循环它并收紧它几次，创造一个＆＃34;螺旋锁和＃34;不需要蜡或粘合剂，但很遗憾，如果有人试图潜行看起来，他们将不得不通过地带撕开，所以她的姐夫会知道这条消息已经被截获。
  苏格兰苏格兰女王远离唯一熟练的艺术＆＃34的人; Letterlocking＆＃34; - 中世纪后期（1250-1500）和早期现代时期（1500-1815），这项技术在整个欧洲变得普遍。通过各种聪明模式的折叠和切割字母，人们试图隐藏他们与不需要的读者的对应，以及＆＃34;锁和＃34;来自无数类型。
 ＆＃34;这不是人们在特殊场合所做的一些特别的东西。这是您在发明信封之前发送信的方式，＆＃34;伦敦大学伦敦国王高校文学中的讲师Daniel Starza Smith。 ＆＃34;所以，如果它＆＃39; sa商业信，如果它＆＃39; sa love letter，如果它＆＃39; sa spy字母，如果它＆＃39; sa外交字母，他们＆＃39;重新使用戴克莱。所以它没有局限于专家，皇室或间谍大师的东西。任何能够发送信函的人都在使用亚太人。＆＃34;
 但在现在，我们＆＃39;只有开始了解技术＆＃39;在历史中的重要性。近年来，明显被遗忘的封锁技巧的整个分类已经被发现。 
当保守者Jana Dambrogio在意大利的梵蒂冈秘密档案馆中的文档缓存中砍伐时，戴锁的现代研究开始了。在2000年代初，她是来自档案馆外的第一名女子＆＃39;在那里允许在那里工作的保守实验室。在她的第一天，她获得了在1500年代后期的Fondo Veneto Sezione II上工作的机会，其中许多尚未修复地图，信件，法律和会计文件的高速缓存。
 当她完成了她的保护工作时，Dambrogio并没有遵循写作，因为它通常在意大利语方言，但她确实注意到了剪纸，折痕和折叠纸。虽然可能弄错了对未经训练的眼睛造成的损害，但她意识到这是凭借戴克莱的证据。所以，她有条理地描述了她观察到了什么。
  当Dambregio返回美国时 - 她现在在马萨诸塞州的麻省理工学院 - 那些原始文件的说明和模型将有用。 ＆＃34;梵蒂冈的数千个字母，但这少数人建模开始帮助我们构建戴克隆的语言，＆＃34;她解释道。
 与Starza Smith连接后，她和她的同事开始寻求更多的遗传锁的例子，无论他们能找到它们，通常都隐藏在旧档案馆和博物馆收藏中。
 几年前，他们遇到了一个特别丰富的赏金：整个行李箱从17世纪的欧洲富有2,600封信，已经未送达 - 其中577个未开封。
  该系列已被一名已婚的邮政管理员和邮政信箱保存，称为Simon Brienne和Marie Germain，他住在荷兰。在1600年代，信件的收件人必须支付以获得它们，因此出于各种原因 - 贫困，搬迁或死亡 - 信件通常未能到达目的地。许多人有文字＆＃34; niet hebben＆＃34;在荷兰语中潦草地潦草地潦草地潦草地说，这意味着＆＃34;拒绝＆＃34;这对夫妇及其员工希望受到收件人最终壳牌的希望，因此昵称：“存钱罐”（Spaarpotje）。无意中，他们编制了这一时期最富有的耶利亚档案之一。
 许多信件都是日常通信，但总的说，他们在1600年代绘制了欧洲生活的详细信息。 ＆＃34;这些信件代表了社会横截面的思想，关心和梦想：大使大使，公爵和公爵，商人，出版商和间谍有可能，也是演员和音乐家，普通恋人，挣扎难民，以及妇女以及男性，＆＃34;写一位研究该系列的研究人员。 
除了他们发现的各种其他来源之外，Brienne系列已允许Dambrogio和Starza Smith确定在早期现代时代人们所知的一系列封锁技术。
 随着时间的推移，这对编译了基本上是一个＆＃34;周期性表＆＃34;封锁。这包括至少18种不同的格式，从最简单的锁定 - 用蜡密封的滚动涡旋滚动 - 一旦密封有12个边缘的分组。根据如何抗篡改，它们还描述了是否具有狭缝或褶皱，以及锁定锁的安全性的属性。虽然一个确定的窥探器可能是可能的，但是在某些情况下，在某些情况下，在某些情况下难以选择，但别无选择，或者撕裂一张纸，或者明显地打破粘合剂的难度。
  我最近在一个在麻省理工学院组织的研讨会上锁定了一封信，让A＆＃34;三角锁和＃34;这个特别的一个不是在Brienne系列中发现的，但是是从欧洲和英格兰的1700年代到1700年代使用的技术。
 令人惊讶的是，我被这个过程的聪明才智击中了。我们从A4张纸和一些录像带开始，达摩码头通过台阶导致我们：＆＃34;从底部切断三角形......折叠短边的短边......不要折叠皱折弯曲它......用一点点狭缝，穿过小三角形。＆＃34;
 我们最终看起来有点像这样。通过字母戳的三角形，然后折叠在边缘上并用胶水或蜡粘在一起。
  您可以使用此视频演示或下面的Team＆＃39;如下图所示，尝试自己的三角锁。
 图中的第二个（中间）是在Brienne收藏中的两个表兄弟之间的一封信中的模型，即最近的团队＆＃34;实际上展开＆＃34;使用X射线显微镜图。这意味着它们可以打开折叠而无需悬垂任何锁。 
如果你想要一个真正的折叠挑战，第三个（底部）被称为＆＃34;匕首陷阱＆＃34;基于英国情报信，从意大利发出1601年，该算子和Starza Smith在英国国家档案。它是我们遇到的最安全，复杂，耗时的信件，我们遇到了最安全，复杂，耗时的信件;虽然它似乎是来自外面的简单褶皱的信，但它基本上是笨拙的困难，其中一个隐藏的纸条内部＆＃34;旅行＆＃34;打开时，揭示它已被解锁。 （这个视频步行可能有所帮助。）
  今天，当人们考虑将他们的消息保持从窥探的眼睛中，他们倾向于专注于数字通信，例如＆＃34;端到端加密＆＃34; WhatsApp或信号等服务。但是，戴克莱斯表明，安全沟通的冲动比许多人更旧。
 ＆＃34;就像人类走过地球并想要记录一些东西，那里有一直需要有自由裁量权，＆＃34; Dambrogio说。古希腊人和埃及人使用密封件对通信和通知。和千年前的中奥泊托米亚的文件往往被封装在叫做大疱的粘土信封中。
 篡改沟通的这些技巧有时甚至在关键历史事件中发挥了作用。当玛丽女王的苏格兰人锁定了她的上一封信时，她敏锐地意识到执政权力可能读到她的信息，并希望她的姐夫知道他们是否已经知道。毕竟，先前截获的信是她面临她的困境的原因：她被授权授权刺激伊丽莎白第一块。
 此外，当时戴克莱成为一种新镜头，以查看历史，并以几个世纪以来我们寻求彼此相互联系的方式。作为Starza Smith指出了玛丽的重要性和＃39;最终行为的意义：＆＃34;人们经常说她在被执行之前的最后一件事就是写一封信。不对！她所做的最后一件事就是锁一封信。＆＃34;
    通过在Facebook上喜欢我们加入一百万个未来的粉丝，或在推特或Instagram上关注我们。
 如果您喜欢这个故事，请注册每周BBC.com功能时事通讯，称为“基本名单”。每周五，英国广播公司的未来，文化，工作期和旅行，文化，工作期和旅行，文化，工作期和旅行的精心挑选。
note_en:
Hundreds of years ago, people developed ingenious methods to secure their letters from prying eyes – and they did it with only paper, adhesive and folds.
 Late at night on 8 February 1587, an imprisoned Mary Queen of Scots composed her  last ever letter to her brother-in-law. "Tonight, after dinner, I have been advised of my sentence: I am to be executed like a criminal at eight in the morning," she wrote. "The Catholic faith and the assertion of my God-given right to the English crown are the two issues on which I am condemned." With a sad acceptance of her fate, she asked him to take care of her affairs and pay her servants, wishing him "good health and a long and happy life".
 After Mary had finished writing, she then began to fold up the letter to secure its contents. She didn't want her captors snooping – and particularly not her cousin Queen Elizabeth I. However, envelopes were not used in the 1500s – not least because paper was expensive – and there was no trustworthy postal service at the time.
 Instead, Mary cut a thin strip from the paper margin, before folding up her message into a small rectangle. After poking the knife through the rectangle to make a hole, she then fed the strip through, looping it and tightening it a few times, creating a "spiral lock". No wax or adhesive was required, but crucially, if someone tried to sneak a look, they would have to rip through the strip, so her brother-in-law would know the message had been intercepted.
  Mary Queen of Scots was far from the only person who was skilled in the art of "letterlocking" – the technique became common throughout Europe during the Late Middle Ages (1250-1500) and Early Modern periods (1500-1815). By folding and cutting letters in various clever patterns, people attempted to hide their correspondence from unwanted readers, and the "locks" came in myriad types.
 "This isn't something special that people do on special occasions. This is how you send a letter before the envelope is invented," explains Daniel Starza Smith, a lecturer in Early Modern English literature at King’s College London. "So, if it's a business letter, if it's a love letter, if it's a spy letter, if it's a diplomatic letter, they're all using letterlocking. So it's not something confined to experts, royalty or spy masters. Anyone who is capable of sending a letter is using letterlocking."
 But in the present day, we're only beginning to understand the technique's importance in history. In recent years, a whole taxonomy of apparently forgotten letterlocking tricks have been uncovered.
    The  modern study of letterlocking began when the conservator Jana Dambrogio was leafing through a cache of documents in the Vatican Secret Archives in Italy. In the early 2000s, she had been the first woman from outside the archive's conservation laboratory who was allowed to work there. On her first day, she was offered the chance to work on the  Fondo Veneto Sezione II, a cache of maps, letters, legal and accounting documents from the late 1500s, many of which had not been repaired.
 As she completed her conservation work, Dambrogio didn't always follow the writing, since it was often in old Italian dialects, but she did notice cuts, creases and folds in the paper. While it could be mistaken for damage to the untrained eye, she realised it was evidence of letterlocking. So, she methodically described what she observed.
  When Dambrogio returned to the US – she's now based at MIT in Massachusetts – those notes and models of the original documents would come in useful. "There are probably thousands of letters of the Vatican, but this handful that I modelled started to help us build the language of letterlocking," she explains.
 After connecting with Starza Smith, she and her colleagues began to seek out more examples of letterlocking wherever they could find them, often hidden away in old archives and museum collections.
 A few years ago, they came across one particularly rich bounty: a whole trunk full of 2,600 letters from 17th-Century Europe which had gone undelivered – 577 of which were unopened.
  The collection had been kept by a married postmaster and postmistress called Simon Brienne and Marie Germain, who lived in the Netherlands. In the 1600s, the recipients of letters had to pay to receive them, so for various reasons – poverty, relocation or death – letters often failed to reach their destination. Many had the words " niet hebben" scribbled on them in Dutch, which means "refused". The couple and their employees kept them in the hope that recipients might eventually shell out, hence the trunk's nickname: “the piggy bank” ( spaarpotje). Inadvertently, they had compiled one of the richest epistolary archives of the period.
 Many of the letters were everyday correspondence, but collectively they paint a detailed picture of life in Europe during the 1600s. "The letters represent the thoughts, cares, and dreams of a cross-section of society: there are missives by ambassadors, dukes and duchesses, merchants, publishers, and spies, but also by actors and musicians, ordinary lovers, struggling refugees, and by women as well as men," write the researchers who have been  studying the collection.
  Along with various other sources they found, the Brienne Collection has allowed Dambrogio and Starza Smith to identify a range of letterlocking techniques known to people during the Early Modern Age.
 Over time, the pair have compiled what is essentially a  "periodic table" of letterlocking. This includes at least 18 different formats, ranging from the simplest of locks – a rolled scroll sealed with wax – to a packet which has 12 edges once sealed. They also describe attributes such as whether they feature slits or tucks, as well as rating the security of locks, according to how tamper-resistant they would have been. While it might have been possible for a determined snooper to reinstate some locks undetected, the difficulty of doing so varied – in some cases, they'd have no choice but to rip a strip of paper, or visibly break the adhesive.
  I had a go at locking a letter myself recently in a workshop that the pair organised at MIT, making a "triangle lock". This particular one wasn't found in the Brienne Collection, but was a technique used from the 1400s to the 1700s across Europe and England.
 It was surprisingly complex, and I was struck by the ingenuity of the process. We started with an A4 sheet of paper and some tape, with Dambrogio leading us through the steps: "cut off a triangle from the bottom… fold short edge to short edge…don't make a sharp crease, just bend it …make a little slit and thread the little triangle through."
 And what we ended up with looked a bit like this. The triangle shape, poked through the letter, is then folded over the edges and stuck down with glue or wax.
  You can try the triangle lock for yourself using  this video demonstration, or the team's diagram below, along with two others that they have identified.
 The second one in the diagram (middle) is modelled after a letter between two cousins from the Brienne Collection that the team recently  "virtually unfolded" using X-ray microtomography. This meant that they could open up the folds without having to unseal any of the locks.
 And if you fancy a true folding challenge, the third (bottom) is called the "dagger trap", based on a British intelligence letter, sent from Italy in 1601, which Dambrogio and Starza Smith found in the UK National Archives. It was "the most secure, complicated, and time-consuming letter we’ve encountered". While it would have appeared to be a simple pleated letter from the outside, it was essentially booby-trapped, with a hidden strip of paper inside that "trips" when opened, revealing it had been unlocked. (This  video walk-through may help.)
  Today, when people think about keeping their messages secure from prying eyes, they tend to focus on digital communication, such as the "end-to-end encryption" of services such as WhatsApp or Signal. But letterlocking demonstrates that the urge to communicate securely is much older than many might assume.
 "As far back as humans have walked the Earth and wanted to document something, there's been a need to have discretion," says Dambrogio. The Ancient Greeks and Egyptians used seals for correspondence and notarisation. And the documentation of Mesopotamia, thousands of years ago, was often encased in clay envelopes called  bullae.
 These tricks for tamper-resistant communication have sometimes even played a role in pivotal historical events. When Mary Queen of Scots locked her last letter, she was acutely aware that the ruling powers might read her message, and wanted her brother-in-law to know if they did. After all, a previously intercepted letter was the reason that she faced her predicament: she had been caught authorising a plot to assassinate Elizabeth I.
 In this light, then, letterlocking becomes a new lens through which to view history and the ways we have sought to connect with one another over the centuries. As Starza Smith points out about the significance of Mary's final actions: "People often say the last thing she did before she was executed was to write a letter. Not true! The last thing she did was to  lock a letter."

title: 聪明的折叠秘密
title_en: The clever folds that kept letters secret
